subject: RE: [junit] separating test data from test code.
msgSnippet: If you don t want to use JXUnit, you could code your own test cases that would be super classes to the test cases that you will run.  These super classes could
messageBody:
If you don't want to use JXUnit, you could code your own test cases that
would be super classes to the test cases that you will run. These super
classes could contain all of the test data you need or invoke on an XML file
that you create to contain the data.

FWIW: JXUnit doesn't seem to be *that* much of a learning curve once you get
past the documentation ;)

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Laird, William [mailto:blaird@...]
> Sent: Wednesday, June 20, 2001 11:16 AM
> To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
> Subject: [junit] separating test data from test code.
>
>
> I'm a QA weenie, with a coding background. I will be
> using JUnit as a
> framework to do API testing for an API that other
> developers wrote. I would
> like to keep test data separate from the test code. I
> could see this test
> data being read from an XML file, or quite possibly being
> retrieved from a
> database via JDBC, or both.
>
> I'm wondering if there has been any discussion on this,
> or if anyone knows
> of any extensions that have already "invented the wheel"
> in this area. I've
> looked at JXUnit, but it seems as if the learning curve
> is a bit too much
> for me to take it on right now.
>
> Thanks,
> Bill Laird
>
>
> BTW, if there are any yahoo groups administrators reading
> this... please
> take my membership status from "pending" to "approved" in
> the yahoo
> groups... thanks.
>
